_prev_prog_2.Description: Anhydrous Ammonia Storage. The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessels to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training on new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine the comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its personnel on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The owners, management, and employees of this facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  This facility complies with the Iowa Department of Ag & Land Stewardship's requirements for anhydrous ammonia storage and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia should occur, it is our policy to notify the City of Preston Fire Department and the Jackson County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and environment.

This facility is a retail fertilizer plant.  We sell fertilizer and pesticides to area farmers.  Anhydrous is used as a form of nitrogen for crop use.  Our storage system consists of two 8,000 gallon tanks with plumbing.

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with the Iowa Department of Ag & Land Stewardship.

This facility has never had an accident involving anhydrous that caused death, injury, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.

This facility has an emergency action plan.  In the event of an anhydrous ammonia emergency, it is our policy to notify the Preston Fire Department and the Jackson County LEPC and request they respond to the emergency.  Employees should evacuate the area.  We have discussed this policy with the Preston Fire Department and the department members have inspected our anhydrous system.

Safety is an ongoing effort with the administration and employees working hand and hand to promote safety through training and continued effort to maintain the facility.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Preston, Iowa location is John Eberhart, operations manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Secti

on of this document. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:
